sections.title: Speaking Patterns: Discussing Your Topic
sections.introduction: These sentence patterns will help you express your ideas about the topic clearly and confidently.

frames.title: Opinion and Reason Pattern

structureComponents.label: Opinion Verb
structureComponents.description: A verb that expresses your viewpoint
structureComponents.inSentenceExample: I [Opinion Verb] this topic is important.

structureComponents.label: Main Idea
structureComponents.description: Your main point about the topic

examples.completeSentence: I think this topic is important because it affects everyone's daily life.
I believe we should learn about this because it helps us understand the world better.

breakdown.Reason: it helps us understand the world better

teachingNotes: Start with familiar opinion verbs like 'think' and 'believe'
Encourage students to give specific, personal reasons
Practice connecting opinions to the lesson topic

sections.title: Fill in the Blanks
sections.text: This is a paragraph about your topic with some [1:important] words removed. Students need to [2:choose] the correct words from the word bank to [3:complete] the text. The missing words should be [4:vocabulary] from the lesson that help students [5:practice] using new terms in context.
sections.teacherNotes: Read the text aloud first, then let students work individually or in pairs to fill in the blanks.

questions.paragraphContext: Many people have different experiences with this topic. Some find it challenging at first, but with practice, they develop confidence and skills. Personal experiences often shape how we view and approach new learning opportunities. The way we first encounter something can influence our long-term relationship with it.
questions.question: How did you first learn about this topic, and what was your initial reaction?
questions.imagePrompt: An illustration showing someone learning something new with curiosity and interest. No text visible.

questions.paragraphContext: Research shows that different methods work better for different people when it comes to learning and understanding new concepts. Some prefer hands-on experience, while others learn better through reading or listening. Cultural background and personal learning style both play important roles in how we process new information.
questions.question: What learning method works best for you when studying this type of topic? Why?
questions.imagePrompt: An illustration showing different learning methods like reading, listening, and hands-on practice. No text visible.

questions.paragraphContext: In today's world, this topic has become increasingly relevant to many aspects of daily life. Technology and social changes have created new opportunities and challenges related to this subject. Understanding current trends and future developments helps us prepare for what's coming next.
questions.question: How do you think this topic will change or develop in the future?
questions.imagePrompt: An illustration showing future developments or technological changes. No text visible.

questions.paragraphContext: Different cultures and communities approach this topic in various ways. What works in one place might not work in another due to different values, resources, or circumstances. Learning from diverse perspectives helps us develop a more complete understanding of complex issues.
questions.question: How is this topic viewed or handled differently in your culture compared to others?
questions.imagePrompt: An illustration showing diverse cultural perspectives or approaches. No text visible.

questions.paragraphContext: Making personal connections to new topics helps us understand and remember information better. When we can relate new concepts to our own experiences, interests, or goals, learning becomes more meaningful and engaging. These connections also help us apply what we learn in practical ways.
questions.question: Can you think of a specific example from your own life that relates to this topic?
questions.imagePrompt: An illustration showing someone making connections between new learning and personal experience. No text visible.

grammarSpotlight.title: Present Simple: Expressing Facts and Habits
grammarSpotlight.description: The present simple helps you talk about facts, regular activities, and general truths about your topic.

logicExplanation.communicationNeed: When discussing this topic, you often need to state facts, describe regular activities, or explain how things generally work.
logicExplanation.logicalSolution: The present simple tense provides a clear, straightforward way to express these ideas without worrying about time complications.
logicExplanation.usagePattern: Use present simple when talking about what always happens, what is generally true, or what regularly occurs with this topic.
logicExplanation.communicationImpact: Using present simple makes your explanations clear and helps listeners understand factual information easily.

teachingTips: Start with the communication need: Why do we need to state facts clearly?
Students often overthink tense choice - emphasize that present simple is for general truths
Practice with facts about the lesson topic before moving to personal examples

examples.sentence: Many people use this method to solve everyday problems.
examples.highlighted: Many people **use** this method to **solve** everyday problems.
examples.explanation: The verbs 'use' and 'solve' are in present simple because they describe what generally happens - a regular pattern or fact.

examples.sentence: This approach works well when people need quick results.
examples.highlighted: This approach **works** well when people **need** quick results.
examples.explanation: Both 'works' and 'need' describe general truths about the approach and people's requirements.

visualSteps.instruction: Identify when you're talking about facts, habits, or general truths

visualElements.elements: Look for words like 'always', 'usually', 'generally', 'every day' or statements that are simply true

visualSteps.instruction: Use the base form of the verb (add 's' for he/she/it)

visualElements.guidance: For facts about the topic: I/You/We/They + base verb, He/She/It + verb + s

visualSteps.instruction: Check your meaning - does this happen regularly or is it generally true?

successTips: Use present simple for topic explanations

pedagogicalApproach.learningObjective: Students will be able to state facts and describe regular activities related to the lesson topic using present simple tense
practiceActivities: Create five facts about the lesson topic using present simple
Describe your regular activities related to this topic
pedagogicalApproach.realWorldApplication: Use present simple when explaining how things work, describing processes, or sharing factual information in conversations and presentations

adaptiveFeatures.levelAdjustment: B1 level focuses on accurate use of present simple for explanations and factual statements
adaptiveFeatures.scaffolding: Step-by-step visual guides help students identify when and how to use present simple correctly
adaptiveFeatures.extension: Advanced students can combine present simple with other tenses to create more complex explanations
